image.altText: Natalie Keley wears a blue shirt at Go Between Bridge, where her sister Teisha Keley was found dead

items.synopsis: Many would have passed by the tangled mess of tents, swags and junk that made up a homeless camp along a riverside walkway in Brisbane's CBD, but no-one realised they were walking past a dead body.

title.children: Tragedy under a city bridge: How a homeless woman was neglected in death as she was in life

image.altText: A composite photo of two women and two men.

items.synopsis: Police have laid out the chain of events they will allege led to a horror triple fatal north of the Sunshine Coast.

title.children: Good Samaritan chased into oncoming traffic before triple fatal crash, police allege

image.altText: John margerison

items.synopsis: A businessman who has "severed all relations" with Australia and left the country is the key to unravelling accusations made under parliamentary privilege that a Canberra consulting firm planned to funnel payments to former minister Stuart Robert.

title.children: Shorten says businessman who left country is the 'key link' in Stuart Robert contracts saga

image.altText: A man on a boat at sunset.

items.synopsis: When Liza Putzka's husband was diagnosed with terminal cancer they were forced to wind down their Spanish mackerel fishing business. She always thought she could sell their licence and boat and retire comfortably — but that is not the case.

title.children: Tragic news forced this fisher back to land. After decades of hard work, his wife is about to be left with nothing

image.altText: Women wearing red soccer jerseys walking onto a green pitch

items.synopsis: Had Morocco qualified for the Women’s World Cup a decade ago, a player who wanted to wear the hijab during a game might have been forced to choose between faith and football.

title.children: Hijabs were only authorised by FIFA in 2014 — Nouhaila Benzina is the first to wear one at the Women's World Cup

image.altText: A composite of a woman with long blonde hair, and a young person holding an Adidas sneaker.

items.synopsis: When Sarah Luke found out her personal details had been shared on the dark web, she never imagined it would lead to two US court actions and a million-dollar damages bill.

title.children: Byron Bay data breach victim told to pay Adidas, National Basketball Association $US1.2m by US courts

image.altText: smiling older man looking at camera

items.synopsis: Good Samaritan Terry Bishop had been travelling to Brisbane on Friday to attend a family member's wedding. Family members say he was a man who would go out of his way to help anyone.

title.children: 'Absolutely devastated': Bruce Highway triple-fatal victim Terry Bishop had been travelling to family wedding

image.altText: Pilot sitting in the cockpit of a small plane.

items.synopsis: Former US Marine pilot Daniel Duggan speaks publicly for the first time from his prison cell as he fights extradition to the United States over allegations he trained Chinese military pilots more than a decade ago.

title.children: Australian 'Top Gun' pilot speaks publicly for the first time since his arrest for allegedly training Chinese military pilots

image.altText: Black and white photo of large crowd of people, many squinting into the sun, aboard a boat, just visible.

items.synopsis: In 1975, Indonesia troops invaded Timor-Leste, targeting, among others, the Chinese Hakka ethnic minority. These people remember what the day was like.

title.children: Four decades ago soldiers killed their family and friends. Today they celebrate their own survival

image.altText: A woman in an wheelchair next to a bike rack

items.synopsis: Paralympian Karni Liddell says she felt unsafe in her own home after thieves broke into her car park and stole her mobility equipment, which followed her car getting stolen late last year.

title.children: Paralympian to prove to NDIS she's still disabled after thieves steal her mobility equipment

image.altText: The inside of a warehouse showing stacks of soft plastics, with some closer up.

items.synopsis: The major supermarkets have started sending samples of soft plastics overseas to be recycled, as they deal with the legacy of thousands of tonnes of stockpiled plastics from the collapsed REDcycle scheme.

title.children: Thousands of tonnes of soft plastics could be sent offshore, as supermarkets look to restart local recycling program

image.altText: A man looks up at the sky in apparent disappointment.

items.synopsis: As Australia looks to win its first Ashes series on English turf in 22 years, Zak Crawley says a 2-2 result would be fair.

title.children: England opener says drawn Ashes series would be 'fair' as Australia hunts for 22-year first

image.altText: A young women in suit with a laptop

items.synopsis: Australia is in dire need of highly skilled researchers in the science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) sector, but many report being stranded in their home country, unable to do their work here due to visa delays.

title.children: Australia is desperate for engineers like Sara — but she can't enter the country

image.altText: A blonde white woman smiles in the front seat of a small pink convertable, next to a photo of a man in a hat smoking a cigarette

items.synopsis: Independent cinemas in regional Australia say the so-called Barbenheimer weekend led to a fourfold increase in ticket sales, which was much needed after the pandemic changed the way people watched movies.

title.children: Dual release of blockbusters Barbie and Oppenheimer a shot in the arm for independent cinemas

image.altText: A platypus in a river, ripples in the muddy water.

items.synopsis: Despite flooding rains across most of the state last year, parts of NSW this year are in drought. Animal conservationists are concerned about the impact these dry conditions could have on monotremes.

title.children: Platypus rescue hospital to open to combat looming drought

image.altText: A woman with brown short hair sits behind a microphone

items.synopsis: Senior public servant Kathryn Campbell resigns from the Department of Defence after coming under heavy criticism for her role in the Robodebt scandal.

title.children: Senior public servant in Robodebt scheme resigns from Department of Defence

image.altText: Sam Kerr with a bandage on her left calf at a Matildas training session in Brisbane.

items.synopsis: The extent of Sam Kerr's injury remains a mystery after Matildas youngster Kyra Cooney-Cross caused a brief panic by mistakenly saying her teammate had torn her calf.

title.children: Matildas play down panic over Kerr injury after teammate's slip of the tongue

image.altText: A German striker makes a phone call gesture with her hand as she receives congratulations for a goal.

items.synopsis: Alex Popp and the German team have made the biggest impression so far at the Women's World Cup — they may have plenty of bigger challenges to come, but a first title since 2007 could well be on the table, writes Kate O'Halloran.

title.children: Dominant Germany lay out impressive case for Women's World Cup favouritism

image.altText: An older man and woman smile in front of a billboard showing a house that had been sold at an auction.

items.synopsis: Higher interest rates and rising house prices have not deterred migrants, retirees and first home buyers relying on "the bank of mum and dad" from buying property, despite data showing a lower number of property settlements.

title.children: The Lindemans bought their new home at auction — and paid in cash. They're part of a growing trend

image.altText: A woman wearing a blue shirt and gloves kneels in the dirt next to a bucket as she reaches into a hole with a small tool

items.synopsis: More than eight decades after Australian soldiers were transferred from temporary graves on the Kokoda Track to a wartime cemetery, a chance discovery reveals the task was never quite completed.

title.children: Chance encounter reveals partial remains of Australian soldiers who died on the Kokoda Track

image.altText: Zach Smith at a press conference.

items.synopsis: CFMEU national secretary Zach Smith says more than half a trillion dollars is needed to meet Australia's demand for social and affordable housing, and the only way to raise the funds is to introduce a "circuit-breaker" tax.

title.children: Construction union boss says tax on super profits needed to meet affordable housing demand

image.altText: Protesters demonstrate following a parliament vote on a contested bill.

items.synopsis: The bill passed by a 64-0 vote after opposition politicians abandoned the Knesset plenum in protest.

title.children: Israel's parliament ratifies contested law limiting Supreme Court powers, sparking protests

image.altText: A woman stands in red smoke, shouting into a megaphone

items.synopsis: Defying threats from protesters and a plea from the United States, Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has forged ahead with a bill that could push his nation towards a constitutional crisis. Here's how it all unfolded.

title.children: Israel's wild 24 hours explained: Heart surgery, a controversial vote and a country on the brink

image.altText: a man in a simple black jacket sits behind microphones

items.synopsis: China's economy is in serious trouble. The country's property sector, once a powerhouse of national economic growth, is in meltdown — and there are predictions of worse to come, writes Ian Verrender.

title.children: China's economy is in serious trouble — and it's bad news for Australia

image.altText: A man wearing a tiger headdress and yellow robe

items.synopsis: Football fans wearing tiger headdresses, hair flowers and flowing yellow, blue and red flags have come from across Sydney to pump up the Colombian national team ahead of today's match.

title.children: 'Runs in our blood': Colombia fans promise passion ahead of Women's World Cup match against South Korea

image.altText: Stocks displayed on a screen at the ASX

items.synopsis: Investors are bracing for Australia's inflation data, US tech earnings and global central bank meetings. ASIC launches court action against Vanguard. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX on the rise, ASIC takes Vanguard to court alleging greenwashing

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Investors are increasingly concerned about where their money is going, in terms of being ethically conscious, ASIC's deputy chair Sarah Court has told senior business correspondent Peter Ryan. The corporate regulator has brought a Federal Court case against Vanguard for alleged 'greenwashing', or misleading investors about the environmental, social, and corporate governance screening applied to their investments. The case centres on a particular Vanguard fund, after the company identified and reported a breach in its product disclosure statement to ASIC. Here's more of what Sarah Court had to say: "What we're really concerned about here was screening that was purported to exclude any bonds from this investment fund that had significant business activities in fossil fuels. "And the significance of this case from ASIC's perspective is that we allege, firstly, that there were large numbers of these bonds in the fund that were actually not researched or screened at all. "And then furthermore, that at one particular time that we're concerned about, there were a number of bonds being invested in from issuers that we say did have significant business activities in fossil fuels, names like Chevron Phillips, Newcastle Coal, the Korean National Oil Corporation and a number of others." Vanguard says it's cooperated with ASIC. The regulator is seeking civil penalties. "We acknowledged the self report and we took that, investigated and we were sufficiently concerned with the extent of the conduct and the representations that were made that were determined to take court action on this occasion," Ms Court said. You can listen to that full interview on The World Today from 12pm on ABC local radio or anytime on the ABC Listen app .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Greenwashing' a concern for ethically conscious investors: ASIC

children.content: Investors are increasingly concerned about where their money is going, in terms of being ethically conscious,
ASIC's deputy chair Sarah Court
has told senior business correspondent
Peter Ryan

The corporate regulator has brought a Federal Court case against Vanguard for alleged 'greenwashing', or misleading investors about the environmental, social, and corporate governance screening applied to their investments.
The case centres on a particular Vanguard fund, after the company identified and reported a breach in its product disclosure statement to ASIC.
Here's more of what Sarah Court had to say:
"What we're really concerned about here was screening that was purported to exclude any bonds from this investment fund that had significant business activities in fossil fuels.
"And the significance of this case from ASIC's perspective is that we allege, firstly, that there were large numbers of these bonds in the fund that were actually not researched or screened at all.

"And then furthermore, that at one particular time that we're concerned about, there were a number of bonds being invested in from issuers that we say did have significant business activities in fossil fuels, names like Chevron Phillips, Newcastle Coal, the Korean National Oil Corporation and a number of others."
Vanguard says it's cooperated with ASIC. The regulator is seeking civil penalties.

"We acknowledged the self report and we took that, investigated and we were sufficiently concerned with the extent of the conduct and the representations that were made that were determined to take court action on this occasion," Ms Court said.
You can listen to that full interview on
The World Today
from 12pm on ABC local radio or
anytime on the ABC Listen app

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australians became a little more optimistic about their finances last week, pushing consumer confidence very slightly higher, according to the ANZ-Roy Morgan weekly index. But the 2.6 point increase to 75.2 points still leaves the index well below the average since 1990, which is 111.1. ANZ senior economist Adelaide Timbrell says that still leaves confidence stuck at recessionary levels. "The average confidence level was at its highest since the first week of June but has now stayed below the 80 mark for 21 weeks — one week shy of the record in the 1990–91 recession ," she noted. Renters drove the bounce in confidence, perhaps on reports that the surge in rents seen over the past year or so might be about to ease. However, despite a very small uptick, those paying off a mortgage remain most pessimistic, with a confidence reading around 68 points. Weekly inflation expectations eased 0.2 of a percentage point to 5.4%. Official figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics, out tomorrow, are expected to show that consumer prices rose an average of about 6% over the year to June.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Consumer confidence edges up but poised to break 1990s recession record

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's early days as far as the local session goes but so far, Australian stocks are tracking higher. The ASX 200 has gained around a third of a per cent, and that's despite falls for financials and consumer stocks. The major miners are leading the charge, with BHP up 2.1 per cent and Fortescue gaining more than 3 per cent, putting both among the top 10 performers in early trade. Energy stocks are also on the rise thanks to a boost from an overnight rise in crude oil prices. Here are the biggest percentage moves on the benchmark index so far: Top 5 Chalice Mining: +6.3% Domain: +5.3% Sayona Mining: +5% Monadelphous Group: +4.3% Champion Iron: +3.5% Bottom 5 Core Lithium : -11.8% Domino's Pizza: -2.6% Allkem: -2.5% Lake Resources: -2.1% Polynovo: -1.8%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX on the rise in early trade, as miners surge

children.content: It's early days as far as the local session goes but so far, Australian stocks are tracking higher.
The ASX 200 has gained around a third of a per cent, and that's despite falls for financials and consumer stocks.
The major miners are leading the charge, with BHP up 2.1 per cent and Fortescue gaining more than 3 per cent, putting both among the top 10 performers in early trade.
Energy stocks are also on the rise thanks to a boost from an overnight rise in crude oil prices.

image.altText: Two men walk off a cricket field looking cold and wet.

items.synopsis: Andrew McDonald defends the captaincy of Pat Cummins after the Australian skipper was criticised for his tactics at Old Trafford.

title.children: 'Opinions that we respect and opinions that we don't': Australian coach hits out at former keeper over Cummins comments

image.altText: James Heappey addressing UK and Ukrainian military personnel in Ukraine.

items.synopsis: Visiting UK Armed Services Minister James Heappey flags the possibility of British troops being eventually stationed in Darwin.

title.children: UK minister tells Australia Ukraine can win if support is kept up

image.altText: A night time photo of a Queensland Police Service car with its blue light illuminated.

items.synopsis: Queensland Police Commissioner Katarina Carroll says a small cohort of offenders are committing more crime and and it's more violent than before.

title.children: 'Phenomenal' arrest figures as 14,000 charges laid in Queensland police operation targetting young offenders

image.altText: A man inside a man-made hole with stones around pointing at an ancient tomb with yellow sand and dirt around.

items.synopsis: Archaeologists find at least 125 tombs in a 2,000-year-old Roman cemetery discovered in Gaza last year, most with skeletons still largely intact, and two rare lead sarcophaguses.

title.children: Rare dolphin-adorned sarcophagus among tombs discovered at a Roman-era cemetery
